abstract: The Department of the Army has identified long wave infrared (LWIR) polarimetry as a means for enhanced detail of human imagery for facial recognition. In addition, polarimetry has been shown to improve image contrast, detect anthropomorphic objects in high clutter scenes, and provide 3D shape information. However, many polarimeters operate using rotating polarization filters or retarders, which result in false polarization signatures in scenes containing movement.For non-cooperative targets, being able to capture the polarization signature of a moving target is essential.In order for the sensor to be operationally useful, the polarization signature must be measured in a single frame.This is typically accomplished using a microgrid polarizer array, in which each pixel has a polarization filter, much like the Bayer filters used on color cameras.However, features that are subpixel can still result in false polarization signatures.IERUS engineers have developed a micro-optic that can optically register the four pixels used to measure the polarization signature.The IERUS approach will integrate the optical registration micro-optic and microgrid polarizer with a cooled dual band IR camera to build the polarimetric sensor and associated processing hardware.

award_title: Magnetic Field Induced Texture to Enhance Magnetic Properties of Polycrystalline Ceramics
research_keywords: Ferrite,Magnetic,texturing,alignment,radar absorbing
abstract: MSRI proposes to demonstrate the concept of magnetic-field assisted texturing in ferrite materials.Aligned microstructure will allow for significantly enhanced magnetic properties.Samples will be prepared by nanopowder synthesis and low temperature sintering.

award_title: Miniature, Software-defined Man-Portable Doppler Radar (MPDR) for Atmospheric Measurement
pi_title: Project Lead - Radar and Sensor Systems
research_keywords: atmospheric remote sensing,Radar,software-define radio,weather radar,dual-use Doppler radar
abstract: BCI will develop a Man-portable Doppler Radar (MPDR) which can be deployed by dismount soldiers in forward operating areas with a minimal size, weight, and power (SWaP) footprint. This radar will provide adverse weather detection in short ranges (greater than 15km) to support forward-area Precision Airdrop (PAD), aviation operations including landing zones and weather hazard warnings. The MPDR system will complement other atmospheric sensors such as Doppler LIDAR systems, demonstrating interoperability with existing power sources and computing nodes and eliminating custom support equipment that must be carried into the field. Software-defined radar transceivers and processing/control nodes will allow for flexibility in the radar performance under different operating conditions and software-driven system upgrades, as well as extensibility of the radar sensor for other missions such as hard target detection for perimeter defense and air surveillance. The Phase I effort will focus on enumerating the strengths and weaknesses of various system architecture approaches and selecting and documenting an initial design approach that maximizes system performance while minimizing the SWaP footprint. The system design concept will be further refined in the Phase I option based on Army feedback and a prototype will be developed, built, and tested in the Phase II effort.

award_title: Miniature, software-defined Man-Portable Doppler Radar (MPDR) for Atmospheric Measurement
research_keywords: Miniature,Software-defined Man-Portable Doppler Radar (MPDR) for Atmospheric Measurement,atmospheric remote sensing,Doppler radar,Software-defined radar,weather radar,Measurement of atmospheric winds and adverse weather features
abstract: Helios Remote Sensing Systems, Inc. proposes to develop and demonstrate an innovative compact, man-portable, ruggedized software-defined Doppler RADAR system for the measurement of atmospheric winds and adverse weather features (e.g. thunderstorms, cloud fronts, etc) that will have advanced characteristics such as adjustable RF waveforms allowing for versatile radar adaptability.We will develop an initial design of the proposed miniature, software-defined MPDR system concept.Detailed algorithms for radar signal generation and processing will be evaluated, using a combination of real data and high fidelity simulation for effectiveness in wind and aerosol/cloud detection under various atmospheric conditions.Results will be documented.Strengths and deficiencies will be clearly identified.The preliminary design will be configured with optimized performance and ready to be implemented in hardware during Phase II.The man-portable design goals are for the overall system to weigh less than 20Kg and have a volume less than 30L.The system will be designed to be capable of measuring atmospheric winds to 10km with adverse weather detected at 15km

award_title: Computationally Driven Development of Energy Absorbing Materials and Manufacturing Processes for Rotorcraft
research_keywords: High Performance Computing,energy absorbing materials,injury biomechanics,rotary wing aircraft
abstract: Corvid Technologies proposes a high fidelity computational physics (HFCP) development approach to achieve the technology improvement goals sought by the U.S. Army and specifically PEO Aviation.Corvids established commercial multi-physics parallel solver Velodyne will be used to analyze highly resolved models using on-site computational facilities comprised of over 20,000 Intel processors. In Phase I, Corvid will leverage ongoing relevant Joint Aircraft Survivability Program Office (JASPO) efforts to model crash events with full airframes, landing gear, and seats of the rotary wing aircraft of interest, along with incorporated occupant models.Corvid will also leverage ongoing advanced human injury modeling capability for the proposed effort. Also in Phase I, Corvid will characterize and further develop EA materials and technologies that effectively improve aircraft survivability.

award_title: Forest/Jungle Positioning Based on Geo-Registered Images from Foliage Penetrating Radar
research_keywords: localization,SOLDIER,GPS,pattern,relational database,registration
abstract: In this proposal, we bring GEO-PIPER (GEO-Registered Images Penetrating Radar).Robotic Research developed localization systems for dismounts in GPS denied environments.Under ARDEC's UMAPS program (Ketula Patel), Robotic Research created the WarLoc system.This small inertial system provides accurate dead reckoning for dismounts.WarLoc has been successfully commercialized.It is being provided to a variety of customers, including: DOD (SOCOM, DHS, and 2nd ID), DHS, and DOE.

award_title: Accurate Position Location Information in GPS-Denied Forests and Jungle Environments
research_keywords: GPS-denied navigation,Position Location Information (PLI),PNT,dismounted soldiers
abstract: Maintaining accurate position location information (PLI) during operational missions is a critical requirement for the dismounted soldier.This requirement is unmet in heavily forested and jungle environments where GPS reception is unavailable due to dense canopy cover.In such environments, soldiers must determine their location by using visual landmarks, or by seeking open clearings where GPS reception can be reestablished.Alternatively, dead-reckoning systems that rely on Inertial Measurement Unit sensor suites can help soldiers maintain PLI over moderate distances, but these devices cannot retain positional accuracy over extended ranges.Creare proposes to address this critical Army need by developing the Tree Position Location Information System.This technological solution will combine a metrology system for determining local tree maps, and geolocalization algorithms that perform spatial pattern matching of local tree maps against a georegistered reference tree map of the operational area.

award_title: Integrated Radar/Optical/Inertial System for Precise Localization under Dense Foliage
research_keywords: Navigation under dense foliage,feature-based navigation,sensor fusion,vision and lidar-aided inertial,deep GPS/inertial integration
abstract: To enable precise positioning capabilities in dense forestry areas, QuNav proposes to develop the technological approach of Positioning with Optical/Inertial Navigation and a Tree-map Enabled by Radar (POINTER). POINTER implements global and local aiding of inertial navigation system (INS) using features extracted from images of electro-optical (EO) sensors (ladar and video camera). Global aiding (i) extracts tree trunks from EO imagery data; (ii) matches them to a geo-referenced map; and, applies matched trunk features to mitigate the INS position drift. Local aiding operates without a priori map information. Position and attitude increments that are computed from a sequence of ladar and video images are utilized for the INS drift mitigation. One key benefit of combining global and local aiding components is the ability of POINTER to operate with sparse maps since local aiding can be applied between absolute position updates.POINTER can be optionally augmented with deeply integrated GPS/INS navigation (DIGINAV). DIGINAV employs long coherent integration to recover extremely weak GPS signals (30 to 40 dB below open-sky conditions). DIGINAV will not necessarily support a continuous position solution under dense canopy. Yet, fragmented satellite measurements can be still recovered thus providing additional updates to the overall sensor-fusion mechanization.

award_title: Innovative X-Band Antenna Architecture for BFT 3
research_keywords: Passive Electronic Phased Array (PESA),Dielectric Filled,Low Cost,Bi-directional
abstract: AMI Research and Development, LLC (AMI), and our small business commercialization partner Mercury Systems, Inc.,propose a novel Passive Electronically Scanned Array (PESA) antenna to bridge the gap between high cost-high performance and low cost-medium performance antenna systems to meet the need forhigh volume phased array antennas for X-Band Satcom-On-The-Move (SOTM) Blue Force Tracking (BFT) applications.This array is referred to as the Dielectric Traveling Wave Array (DTWA).It meets the requirements of the SBIR solicitation A16-032 as in Table 1, and is only 8.0 in. x 8.0 in. x 6.0 in., as shown in Figure 1.The technology enabling the AMI solution is covered by U.S. Patent No. 9,246,230 and U.S. patent applications 13/372,122, 14/702,147, and EP patent application 12 744 769.6, PCT/US2015/028849.A further description of this technology, scaled to Ka-Band, was presented at the 2014 Antenna Applications Symposium at Allerton. The beamforming circuitry of the array consists of parallel dielectric filled waveguides with array elements coupled to the waveguide surfaces. To scan the beam along the waveguide axis, the propagation constant of the waveguides is changed using a reconfigurable layered structure in the waveguide.

award_title: Innovative X-Band Antenna Architecture for BFT 3
research_keywords: X-band,phased-array,full-duplex,single-aperture,antenna,antenna architecture,feed system
abstract: To enable the operation of Blue Force Tracking over the WGS satellite constellation, Envistacom proposes a phased array panel solution that is steered mechanically in the azimuth direction and steered electronically in elevation, giving full 360 degree azimuth coverage and -50 to 90 degree elevation coverage.Envistacom will use a combination of innovative panel design, filtering, and signal processing to address the problem of transmit-receive isolation at X-band.The proposed solution will be capable of ARSTRAT certification for operation on WGS, and it will be compliant with form factor requirements of the Blue Force Tracking program.

award_title: Innovative X-Band Antenna Architecture for BFT 3
research_keywords: WGS compliance,SATCOM,full duplex,isolation,X-band,phased array
abstract: This proposal details the design of key MMIC components architected in a phased array antenna to allow WGS compliance with the MIL-STD-180/164 specification. The proposal draws upon the extensive design experience with GaAs and GaN of Custom MMIC, coupled with the substantial system knowledge of Ball Aerospace. The proposal details how this knowledge of the key system parameters allows us to address such a complex and difficult system with a solution that can be fielded. The technical aspect keys on the need for isolation between transmit and receive in a full duplex system. Each component in the chain will be analyzed and modified to provide the necessary filtering for success. Key aspects of the design have been demonstrated by measurements on an X-band PA with RX notch and the necessary changes for full compliance detailed.

award_title: Multi-Band Body Wearable Antenna
research_keywords: body-wearable antenna,Ultra-Wideband Antenna,ultra-wideband body-wearable antenna
abstract: Under SBIR Topic A16-033, Multi-Band Body Wearable Antenna (MBWA), the U.S. Army seeks a new body wearable antenna design capable of operating effectively in multiple radio frequency bands and with various modulation techniques to provide a minimum range of 0.5 KM when both the transmitter and receiver are situated in horizontal positions on the ground. The MBWA will need to operate effectively in 30 -88, 116174, 225450, and 450-512 MHz for terrestrial communications; and UHF SATCOM band (225-318 MHz circularly polarized) and L-Band (Soldier Radio Waveform). It is desirable that the MBWA can be remoted from the radio and the soldier (i.e.: hoisted into a tree) to increase communications range to 5 KM in heavily forested or triple canopy jungle environments.Prior to 2007, Wang Electro-Opto Corporation (WEO) developed several broadband conformal body wearable antennas with multioctave bandwidths, based on its broadband Traveling-Wave Antennas (TWA), which have been field tested by the Army with good results. Since 2007, WEO invented a new generation of TWAs for the exploding Mobile Wireless applications, such as the smartphones and tablets. Therefore, WEO proposes to develop an MBWA using these patent-protected TWA technologies which have reached TRL and MRL 4 to 7.

award_title: Multi-Band Body Wearable Antenna
research_keywords: Body-wearable,antenna,specific absorption rate (SAR),VHF,UHF,Conformal,man pack radio,Light weight
abstract: Having successfully completed a Phase II program culminating in the delivery of 50 prototype SINCGARS antennas, FIRST RF understands the challenges of body-wearable antenna design and implementation. Given its substantial scope, FIRST RF recognizes that there is considerable risk involved in the Phase I effort. However, instead of starting from square one, FIRST RF will be able to leverage past work to meet the stated objectives of Phase I. Current dismounted radios provide larger spectrum capability than can be met by current body wearable antenna technology. The end goal is to fill the gap between radio capability and limited antenna bandwidth. FIRST RF will generate a comprehensive analysis package that looks at the SAR on the end-user at each of the operating frequencies in order to ensure occupational safety limits are not exceeded.FIRST RF has established the professional experience and the tools to accurately determine radiation exposure levels through both simulation and measurement.

award_title: Directional Antenna Control SYStem (DACSYS) for MANET
research_keywords: Parasitic antennas,Directional Antenna,FPGA,MANET,Routing,MAC
abstract: Wireless connectivity and situational awareness of warfighters are critical in current and future warfare. Maintaining network connectivity and achieving situational awareness require continuous exchange of information across the network, which eventually drives the need for reliable, high data rate communication links. The task of providing high data rate communication is ever more challenging for the Army with the need of providing connectivity in a mobile ad-hoc network (MANET) framework which is known to have fundamental capacity limit. Inclusion of antenna array in MANET framework brings many challenges that have to be overcome.To address this challenge, Intelligent Automation Inc. (IAI) proposes to develop a Directional Antenna Control SYStem (DACSYS) for radios, without modifying radio waveforms. DACSYS is designed to support a wide variety of antenna systems in general and steerable parasitic antenna arrays in particular. DACSYS modules include hardware, firmware, and software. DACSYS hardware includes sensors for estimating 6 degrees of freedom (6 DOF) of position of the antenna system. It also has an FPGA and a processor to support signal processing and antenna control modules.

award_title: Multi Product UHF L-band System Extension (MPULSE)
research_keywords: Iridium,Mobile UHF Objective System (MUOS),Blue Force Tracking (BFT),Production Rifleman Radio (PRR),Position Location Information (PLI)
abstract: Oceanit proposes to develop innovative and efficient methods for broadening the interfacing capability for Position Location Information (PLI) systems to transceiver across multiple wireless systems to enhance PLI reliability.

award_title: Multi Product UHF L-band System Extension (MPULSE)
research_keywords: Successive approximation register,pipelined ADC,digital-RF transceiver,discrete-time mixer,SATCOM,
abstract: Low cost integrated transceiver solutions eliminating the bulk of analog preprocessing are extremely attractive for Satellite Communications (SATCOM), and other wideband RF applications. Building upon the digital-RF transmitter development using 32-nm silicon-on-insulator (SOI) CMOS, we propose to develop a digital-RF transceiver IC that will have an analog RF interface from 290 MHz to 3 GHz and a standard digital interface to commercial-off-the-shelf state-of-the-art FPGAs.In Phase I, we propose to investigate a time-interleaved hybrid pipelined-SAR receiver with an on-chip LC-tank phase locked loop, incorporating regenerative operational amplifiers, thermal noise cancellation and digital calibration techniques to achieve the solicited performance. The digital-RF transmit side performs the reverse operation of the receiver, collecting and combining signals from basebands to form a set of composite transmit signals that are intended to be transmitted over different RF bands. We also propose to extend the analog interface to higher frequencies using either an analog or a discrete-time continuous-amplitude mixer.

award_title: Design of Self Organizing Adaptive Robotic Swarms (DSOARS)
research_keywords: swarm engineering,design patterns,OPTIMIZATION,verification
abstract: Swarms are complex systems that exhibit non-intuitive, emergent behaviors. Current design approaches rely heavily on the expertise of the designer and extensive experimentation and tuning. Soar Technology (SoarTech) proposes to develop a swarm engineering environment for the Design of Self Organizing Adaptive Robotic Swarms (DSOARS). By employing both a top down and bottom up constructive approach DSOARS will fundamentally change how reliable swarming systems are configured and deployed.Effective swarm design must address three core challenges: (1) Decomposing mission tasks into the appropriate atomic behaviors and interactions of the swarm entities to achieve the necessary swarm-level behavior, (2) adapting and tuning the size, configuration, and behavior of the swarm to the specific mission at hand, and (3) verifying that the emergent swarm behavior consistently achieves the mission goals with a high level of confidence.DSOARS addresses these challenges through two primary innovations: (1) verified swarm design patterns and mapping rules to decompose mission tasks into individual behaviors for achieving desired swarm effects and (2) a constructive test and evaluation environment that simultaneously optimizes and verifies a swarm configuration against a wide range of possible mission conditions.

award_title: Stigmergy and State Sharing (S3): Achieving Collective Goals through Individual Robot Behaviors
research_keywords: Swarm intelligence,robotics,Micro-robots,stigmergy,state sharing,Emergent Behavior,rule compiler.
abstract: In swarms of social insects, simple individual actions can lead to the emergence of highly sophisticated collective behavior, capable of performing tasks that range from shortest path discovery to nest construction.Such collective intelligence has served as an inspiration to researchers in robotics, due to the high effectiveness of its underlying mechanisms.However, in adapting such mechanisms to concrete applications, it is necessary to solve a difficult inverse problem: given a desired collective behavior for achieving some goal, automatically generate a set of individual behaviors that will cause the collective behavior to emerge within a swarm of robots.To address this problem, Intelligent Automation, Inc., proposes to develop a system for automatically generating rules that govern individual actions through stigmergy and state sharing (S3).Stigmergy is defined as indirect communication through the environment, where an individual robot determines its action simply based on the observed actions of nearby robots.State sharing allows each robot to update its state based on the states of nearby robots; in turn, state affects which stigmergic rules are applied, allowing for effective coordination in both space and time.Our system will generate stigmergic and state sharing rules for achieving a wide range of swarm goals.

award_title: Predictive Smart-Grid-Enabled Resource Alerting and Management
research_keywords: Predictive,Prognostics,heuristics,Supply Chain Management,Resource management,real time,cognitive,histrionics
abstract: To address the Army need for advanced, real-time, situationally-aware prognostic resource management software tools, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Predictive Smart-Grid-enabled Resource alerting and Management (PSGRM) system. PSGRM is an intelligent resource management solution that predicts future resource status through observation of current usage and real-time situational data (weather, etc.), and tempers this using historical data, thus bringing past experience into play. It is built around a novel predictive resource usage routine that estimates resource usage for current and future times. A real-time situational data module aggregates data from external sources and generates modifier values. Results are stored and used by the histrionics module for refining future predictions. In Phase I, POC will define the requirements and CONOPS, and architect the PSGRM system. We will then fabricate a proof-of-concept prototype and perform a demonstration to Army personnel demonstrating the ability to predict resource usage in response to real-time events, thus directly satisfying the solicitation requirements. In Phase II, POC will expand the capabilities and features, as well as debug and optimize the design. The final Phase II TRL-6 prototype will be ready for transition to productization for follow on Phase IIE/III efforts.

award_title: A Predictive Analytics-based Resource Demand Estimation and a Software Framework for Agile Planning
research_keywords: Forward Operating Base,Energy on Demand,Energy management systems,Predictive Analytics,model-based,data-driven,knowledge-based,decision support
abstract: QSI, leveraging its extensive experience in diagnostics and prognostics of complex NASA, military and commercial systems through its commercial software toolset TEAMS (Testability Engineering and Maintenance System) and research on power quality monitoring and mission planning, seeks to develop a data-driven, self-learning software framework, for context-based (i.e., mission tempo, resource, weather, location and task-based) assessment of critical quantities (e.g., fuel, ammunition, water, food, medical supplies, repair parts, etc.) over time. The software framework, once integrated with the TEAMS toolset, will monitor mission activity (planned or ongoing) data streams to estimate power demands of mission systems, as well as detect and classify mission events (using a trained model from TEAMS-DMin (Data miner) that is automatically embedded in TEAMS-DE (decision engine)), forecast context-sensitive resource demands to meet the COA needs, and provide alerts when the demands exceed the capabilities for altering schedules, selecting alternative COAs, or reducing demands from low priority loads. While the specific focus of demonstration will be on predicting the energy and power needs for systems in a FOB based on forecasts of weather and tempo of operation, the software architecture is generic, modular and extensible in that it can be used to predict all aspects of mission-resource requirements.

award_title: Mission Command Augmented Reality Technologies to enhance Human User Readiness (MCARTHUR)
research_keywords: Mission Command,AUGMENTED REALITY,Visual Psychophysics,Human Factors,visualization,cognitive systems engineering,geospatial
abstract: In recent years, Augmented Reality (AR) technologies have supported users in a variety of domains to enable enhanced situation awareness (SA) and improved decision making. To date, however, no AR approaches have been developed to support Mission Command (MC), despite the importance of MC to all Army missions. To apply AR in support of MC, Charles River Analytics proposes to research, define requirements for, and design and develop prototype Mission Command Augmented Reality Technologies to enhance Human User Readiness (MCARTHUR). First, we will conduct a Focused MC Work Domain Analysis to iteratively develop an inventory of the procedures, skills, and competencies relevant to situational awareness for MC. Second, we will conduct a Scoped AR Trade Study to catalog relevant insights into how humans perceive AR displays, the strengths and limitations of available display platforms and which HCI techniques have been successful for given tasks and contexts. Finally, we will develop a Geospatial AR Prototyping Environment to allow AR designers to quickly design and evaluate visualization and HCI techniques that can be readily transitioned across AR platforms as that technology evolves, and support demonstrations of targeted proof-of-concept MC ARapplications.

award_title: Augmented Reality for Mission Command
research_keywords: AUGMENTED REALITY,Mission Command,Situational awareness,immersive training,Natural Interaction
abstract: Army Commanders often have only as much information about their environment as they can perceive with their own unaided senses and can mentally picture based on subordinate reports. Current tools such as Nett Warrior provide new ways of visualizing information, but require looking down into a computer screen. New tools such as augmented reality (AR) have the potential to make digital information more readily accessible while also allowing soldiers to continue to observe their surroundings. New AR technologies are quickly arriving in the marketplace and have the potential to improve commander situational awareness. However, there has not been a systematic needs assessment across Army warfighter functions, nor an assessment of the technology itself to meet the needs. To fill this gap, we propose to correlate Army warfighting functions against the current state of the art in augmented reality technology including visualization, imaging, and human computer interaction. We will assess situational awareness needs for commanders, the immersive needs for training, and ways to interact naturally with the AR information. We will select a specific application of these technologies that would have a broad impact across Army warfighter functions and conduct a deep analysis to understand the specific information and display requirements.

award_title: Mission Command Enhanced Situational Awareness Display
research_keywords: AUGMENTED REALITY,Situational awareness,Mission Command
abstract: As sensors on the battlefield increase at an exponential rate, the amount of information available to Commanders and Staff of Army Mission Command is, at best, overwhelming. New technologies are emerging, specifically in Augmented Reality (AR), that show great promise to not only helping manage and share information to the Commanders at all levels, but also effectively increase their Situational Awareness (SA) resulting in the capability to execute missions with higher success rates, lower loss of life, reduced time frames, less necessary resources/troops, and reduced fratricide/collateral damage. The ultimate endeavor will be to provide an all-encompassing display approach for mission commanders that gives them the perfect gods eye view of the battlefield, as was imagined in the movie Avatar.Creative Microsystems Corp (CMC) proposes to research and develop a task specific AR system based on the Army Mission Commands requirements. CMC is an expert at integrating AR based systems and is currently developing several advanced see-through wide field of view display systems. We will base our approach on a thorough research effort in the latest display, head/pose tracking, human computer interaction (HCI), haptic feedback, and other AR related technologies in regards to the specific requirements of the users.

award_title: Thin Film High-k Dielectric Semiconductor Materials Development for IRFPAs
research_keywords: Infrared Focal Plane Array,ROIC,Sensors,high- k dielectric,charge storage
abstract: In this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I effort, MicroSol Technologies Inc. and University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) will collaborate to develop a high-k material for application in IR image sensor readout integrated circuits. High-k Al2O3/TiOx nanolaminates will be in-situ deposited by atomic layer deposition (ALD).Material properties will be optimized to achieve a high dielectric constant and low leakage current. 3-D structured metal insulator metal (MIM) capacitors compatible with 180nm and 250nm CMOS foundry process flows will be designed, fabricated, and characterized to demonstrate charge capacitive density greater than 80fF/um2. Material will be characterized and optimized for thickness uniformity, charge density, leakage current, breakdown voltage, and long-term reliability.

award_title: Thin Film High-k Dielectric Semiconductor Materials Development for IRFPAs
research_keywords: MIMCAP,high-k dielectric,ROIC,Infrared Focal Plane Array,charge storage,laminate stacks,BST
abstract: MIM (Metal-Insulator-Metal) capacitors offer a higherlevelofminiaturization,flexibilityandperformancecharacteristicsthan conventionaldiscretecapacitors.MIMCAP's have beenpreparedandcharacterizedwithdifferentkindof stacksanddielectricmaterialsinrecentyears.Theparameterssuchashighdielectricconstant,low dielectricloss,highchargestoragecapacity,andlowleakagecurrentdensityareimportantfactorsin selectingdielectricmaterial.Novati believes that the program goals to achieve charge density >80fF/um2 or >20X of current SiO2 based technology can be achieved using the proper dielectric material.The goal is to chose the right high-k dielectric semiconductor material for high performance, high sensitivity cooled IRFPA's, thereby advancing the Armys current IR imaging technology.Novati will perform ALD fabrication on blanket 200mm wafers and characterize thin film properties such as thickness, roughness, stress and refractive index for multilayer high dielectric constant dielectrics suitable for high capacitive density MIMCAP applications.Candidate high dielectric constant films include TiO2, Ta2O5, HfO2 and ZrO2 and total thickness of multilayer, laminate, stacks will be

award_title: Digital Readout Integrated Circuits With Efficient, Low Power On-chip Data Compression Development
research_keywords: Digital ROIC,DROIC,On-chip data compression,Context-Adaptive Binary Arithmetic Coding,CABAC,DVE,HFI,LOSSLESS
abstract: High data rate digital focal plan arrays offer the warfighter improved situational awareness and target detection and discrimination. However, these benefits are difficult to realize because of high output data rates, high power dissipation, demanding cooling requirements, and limitations on data rates. The proposed 10:1, lossless, on-chip compression, cuts the data rate by an order of magnitude, and by doing so removes the key barriers from the implementation of much needed high performance sensors.Nu-Treks on-chip compression scheme is based on widely used image coding and compression schemes adapted to the specific data flow in digital readout integrated circuits (DROICs). It will also be optimized for typical Degraded Visual Environments (DVE) and Hostile Fire Indicator (HFI) images and war fighter objectives. The compression scheme selected is especially suitable for on-chip implementation as it operates on a single row at a time and involves only addition, subtraction, and bit shifting (multiplication and division by 2), which are easy to implement on chip.Nu-Trek will leverage cutting edge in-house DVE and HFI DROICs to customize and optimize the compression scheme, implement the compression scheme in CMOS, and demonstrate the compression scheme in conjunction with high data rate DROICs.

award_title: Digital Readout Integrated Circuits With Efficient, Low Power On-chip Data Compression
research_keywords: Digital ROIC,Digital IRFPA,On-chip data compression,Sensors,Infrared
abstract: There is a continuing push for very large format, very high dynamic range, very fast frame rate digital Infrared Focal Plane Arrays (IRFPAs) by the DOD community. Some emerging applications require FPA data rates >100 Gb/s; for commonly used Low Voltage Differential Signal (LVDS) output circuits with 1 Gb/s capability, this translates to 100 pairs of Dewar feedthrough wires creating un-manageable power and thermal dissipation. Efficient on-FPA data compression techniques are required to reduce FPA output data rates. On Phase I Black Forest Engineering (BFE) will design a 1k x 1k Digital Readout Integrated Circuit (DROIC) in a 10 m pixel pitch with 18-bit ADC and lossless compression to support the equivalent of 100 Gb/s FPA data rates with

award_title: Digital Readout Integrated Circuits With Efficient, Low Power On-chip Data Compression Development
research_keywords: Infrared FPA,DROIC,DPROIC,large format,high frame-rate,Low Power,lossless compression,lossy compression
abstract: This proposal outlines an on-chip data compression scheme for large format digital pixel readout integrated circuits (DPROICs) to achieve high frame-rates using standard high speed interfaces like Low Voltage Differential Signaling (LVDS). Using a combination of lossless compression and high quality lossy compression, the proposed compressing scheme with enable high quality infrared imaging without requiring high data bandwidths, thereby requiring fewer LVDS ports and in turn reducing power consumption and thermal dissipation. The compression scheme can be readily used in conventional DROICs as well, thereby expanding its application spectrum to most Army and DoD applications. The proposed DPROIC with on-chip data compression will be a complete camera-on-chip architecture when combined with infrared detectors. The DPROIC will be implemented in a mature CMOS process with much more reasonable mask costs as compared to that of state-of-the-art line width processes, saving the government money and broadening the possible supplier base.

award_title: Use of Augmented Reality in Experimentation with New Equipment Training for Electro-Optic Infrared (EOIR) Sensors
research_keywords: augmented reality,perception testing,psycho-physical,Target Acquisition,Electro-Optical Sensors,Infrared Sensors,human-in-the-loop
abstract: We propose to develop and demonstrate reliable, robust and effective methods for presenting and evaluating the combined effects of EO/IR augmented reality and appropriate in-band signatures on human-in-the-loop psycho-physical perception. The overall effort in Phase I will focus on research and development of the experimental design and methodology for augmenting target acquisition performance measurement and experimentation. In addition, we will determine the metrics that will be used to evaluate probability of detection and time to detect. These metrics will in large part determine what and how testing must be conducted and with what type of hardware and software. We strongly believe that success in solving this critical problem will rely on a heuristic approach with significant input from our subject matter experts. Our goal for the proposed effort is to develop and demonstrate a proof-of-concept methodology in Phase I that can lead to a generalized fidelity formulation and prototype in Phase II. The generalized fidelity formulation will allow the simulation community to determine the adequacy and suitability of real-world augmented reality for their specific simulation implementation and application, including testing of EO/IR sensors in various environments.

award_title: Use of Augmented Reality in Experimentation with New Equipment Training for Electro-Optic Infrared (EOIR) Sensors
research_keywords: Augmented-reality,Training,experimental testbed,Target Acquisition,sensor technology,electro-optic/infrared sensors,user centered design,Psychophysics
abstract: To maintain the US Armys nighttime advantage and reduce fratricide due to battlefield complexity, imagers that function in all types of contexts and atmospheric conditions are necessary. Moreover, the complexity of bourgeoning sensor technologies coupled with mission diversity requires a real-to-life, yet cost effective, target acquisition training solution. This efforts objective is to create an augmented reality (AR)-based target acquisition training and experimentation tool that provides comparative, human factors testing and validation of training technologies. Phase I includes a state-of-the-science review to identify AR technologies and authoring tools capable of facilitating EO/IR target acquisition performance. A testbed experimental methodology to assess the integrated components using psychophysical measures to benchmark and predict Soldier performance will be identified. Results will be leveraged to develop and test a software suite that will automate the experimental design and assessment process. Grounded in usability engineering and combined with psychophysical measures, Phase II will test the prototype tool using Soldiers of varying expertise, performing within operationally relevant EO/IR scenarios. Phase II outcomes include a validated target acquisition training scenario and an extensible automated experimental design software capability. Phase III will ultimately deliver an immersive, interactive, cost-effective AR-based training experiment delivery system focused on EO/IR target acquisition.

award_title: Use of Augmented Reality in Experimentation with New Equipment Training for Electro-Optic Infrared (EOIR) Sensors
research_keywords: augmented reality,Embedded Training,perception testing,Target Acquisition
abstract: Training the warfighter to employ new electro-optic infrared (EOIR) sensing technologies for target acquisition requires a realistic representation of operational challenges including threat target profiles, environmental clutter, and sensor engineering limitations. Augmented reality (AR) enables the efficient training by allowing the Soldier to directly focus on the most important items within an EOIR sensor feed. Toyon Research Corporation proposes to develop an experimentation capability for training the target acquisition process by integrating a real-time image processing technology to augment video, a geospatial representation of targets, landmarks, and other geo-referenced items, and a learning management system to enable higher level reasoning in the context of various missions and scenarios. In Phase I, Toyon will develop psychophysical experimentation architectures to identify the most critical training components to vary and stimulate in a live training environment. Toyon will develop a methodology for evaluating the responses to effectively train the Soldier for rapidly acquiring targets. Geospatial data will be displayed on the EOIR feed by using high-fidelity sensor models for estimating target locations. As a result, Toyons proposed approach is display agnostic and will embed on screen display data on existing real-time EOIR monitors.

award_title: Extended Short-Wavelength Infrared Focal Plane Arrays for Hyperspectral Imaging
research_keywords: Type-II,InAs/GaSb/AlSb,InAs/InAsSb/AlAsSb,Superlattice,Infrared,SWIR,SLS
abstract: Hyperspectral imaging at full short- and extended short-wavelength infrared spectral band (0.92.5 m) has important military applications. When used for imaging, a SWIR camera can operate at night using light reflected off the subject in the scene, generating high resolution images with details such as shadows and surface roughness. Compared to thermal infrared imaging, SWIR images look more like visible images and thus scene interpretation is much easier. Even on moonless nights, natural background radiation from the sky, called nightglow, provides useful illumination for imaging. Additional advantages include imaging through glass windows, some types of camouflage, smokes, fires, and haze with less attenuation than visible light. Many objects of military interest, such as explosives and chemicals, disturbed earth, terrain, and vegetation, contain rich and unique spectral features in the SWIR band. The goal of this effort is to demonstrate high-performance extended SWIR photodetectors based on Type-II superlattices. The detector performance goal is the following: quantum efficiency larger than 90% with anti-reflection coating, dark current density less than 710-8 A/cm2 at an operating temperature 200K or higher.

award_title: Extended SWIR Epi Materials Development for Hyperspectral FPA Applications
research_keywords: antimonide,Type II,InGaAsSb,Superlattice,shortwave,Infrared,FPA,SWIR
abstract: This Phase I SBIR proposes to develop high-quality high-performance Extended Short-Wave Infrared (SWIR) detector epitaxy materials based on InGaAsSb quaternary absorber for hyperspectral FPA for imaging applications.The epi materials will be grown on GaSb substrates.The development will focus producing detector epi wafer with cut-off wavelength in the 2 - 3 um Extended SWIR spectral band.The epi materials will be grown with Sb-capable multi-wafer production Molecular Beam Epitaxy (MBE) reactor.

award_title: Extended SWIR Unipolar Barrier Detectors Lattice Matched to GaSb Substrates
research_keywords: Infrared,SWIR,Hyperspectral,detector,unipolar barrier,photodiode,GaSb
abstract: The extended short wavelength infrared (e-SWIR) wavelength band is a performance gap for infrared detectors. At both shorter and longer wavelengths, high performance detector technologies exist: SWIR InGaAs detectors (1.7 m cutoff), and MWIR (3-5 m cutoff) detectors such as InAs-based and GaSb-based Unipolar Barriers, MCT, and InSb. This program proposes development of high performance e-SWIR detectors with cutoff wavelengths in the 2.5 m range, based on lattice-matched InGaAsSb absorber layers on GaSb substrates. The design incorporates a unipolar barrier device architecture that enables the device to be free of the effects of surface leakage currents and generation-recombination dark currents. The design can achieve background-limited (BLIP) performance at T=210K, which is accessible by thermo-electric coolers. The program brings together unique skill sets of two small businessesAmethyst Research who specializes in infrared detector design, development and materials growth, and Attollo Engineering who specialize in FPA fabrication and camera integration. Phase I will demonstrate prototype devices exhibiting dark current 10 times Rule 07 and 85% quantum efficiency. In Phase II FPAs will be fabricated and will be integrated into a thermoelectrically cooled camera, to assess system performance.

award_title: COMPAS: Collection Management Planning using Agent Surrogates
research_keywords: software agents,Plan Optimization,Ontology,Reasoning Algorithm,Semantic Alignment,Disconnected Limited Intermittent (DIL),Collection-Plan Broker (CPB),Surrogate Sensor Agent (SSA)
abstract: ISR collection management planning requires data from a variety of sources spread across a large disconnected, intermittent, and latency challenged networks. As a result, collection management planning relies heavily on the cognitive abilities of the Collection Manager to decide on the best coverage and application of ISR sensor platforms.Intelligent software agent technologies have the ability to help optimize the collection management plan by reaching across some of the boundaries created by the challenging network environment and combining the intermediate results of distributed agents. The COMPAS program was created to test the core concepts of establishing such a software agency. COMPAS software agents will communicate and reason according to a collection management planning ontology, and each specific type of sensor agent will be tuned to the specific parameters and capability set of their respective platform.The collection-plan broker (CPB) will establish a set of collection requirements that will be published to the agency. The agents will assess the set and provide useful metrics related to the requirements they are capable of meeting and the overall costs associated with meeting those requests. With the information provided by each agent, the CBP will identify the best ISR allocation plan.

award_title: Self-Healing ISR Ecosystem (SHIRE)
research_keywords: intelligent agents,ISR Sensors,Mission Management,Self-Healing Network,Anomaly Notification,cross domain solution,Normalcy/Anomaly Detection,sensor management
abstract: Modus Operandi proposes an innovative solution to utilize intelligent agents to detect and configure the best sensor deployment within the full suite of Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) collection capabilities.This distributed, agent-enhanced sensor collection network will allow for quick response to changing mission objectives through a Self-healing ISR Ecosystem (SHIRE) of ISR assets. The current ISR collection is heavily dependent on human guidance and experience to create an effective collection plan.This planning is reliant on the individual setting up the mission and frequently only accounts for the specific mission system that is being utilized.This creates gaps in coverage that can be mitigated by incorporating all available sensors in the mission area.By creating a network of all available sensors without being limited by security domain or mission platform, the entire network can be utilized.Intelligent agents communicate to ensure complete coverage and notify managers when there are gaps in coverage or detection of anomalous data to be investigated.If accepted by the Mission Managers, the sensors can then adjust coverage for complete coverage of the mission areas.

award_title: Enterprise Enabled Intelligent Agents to Optimize Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR) Collection
research_keywords: intelligence agent,collection asset optimization,automated consequence management,sensor modeling,entity modeling,automated asset planning,environment modeling,collection requirements context generation modeling
abstract: Tucson Embedded Systems proposes an intelligent agent based software system for ISR collection management and optimization. The proposed system, Radiant Focus, uses intelligent agents that can be distributed across an enterprise in computational engines to accelerate, automate and optimize the collection of intelligence. The proposal provides a CONOPS for Radiant Focus, and outlines all of the major software subsystems within the Radiant Focus Framework. The proposal also describes how software development processes will be used to manage the development of Radiant Focus with deliverables for Phase I of Requirements Specification, Software Architectures, and a Functional Descriptive Framework of Radiant Focus System and all sub systems. Benefits Statement Radiant Focus will provide the US Army a software framework and associated subsystems for ISR collection management. The subsystems of Radiant Focus each performs specific tasks within the ISR collection management and optimization objectives. A collection requirements engine will intake collection requests and prioritize collection requirements into a master order of merit list. An environment model will provide environmental constraint functions for NAI/XOI such as Line of Sight (LOS), Radio Hear-ability (Link Budget) and Obscurants/Attenuators. Target Entity Models provide models of observable phenomena of entities. Sensor Asset models provide models of sensor capabilities

award_title: Intelligent Unified and Intuitive Data and Information Visualization System
research_keywords: symbology,visualization,Cognitive Load,Information Overload
abstract: To address the Armys need for a new simplified visualization paradigm, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Intelligent Unified and Intuitive Data and Information Visualization (INTUIDIV) system based on an innovative integration of three principles of content simplification: abstraction, augmentation, and registration. Abstraction transforms data or information to a familiar representation that simplifies and improves comprehension; augmentation modifies familiar symbology/iconology to convey additional information at-a-glance with minimal impact to cognitive load; and registration associates content in a spatio-temporal fashion to convey patterns and unseen correlations. The innovation in implementing these three principles in a new visualization paradigm will convey intuitive information in an analog fashion rather than comprehending quantitative information, leading to enhanced global situational awareness. When desired, the user may drill-down for additional details through contextual pop-up menus and view changes, thus allowing lower-level granular exploration as desired. In Phase I, POC plans to identify and validate methodologies for optimizing a users ability to process large amounts of data including initial quantitative performance assessment using simplified data sets and scenarios. In Phase II, POC will develop and demonstrate a prototype system that will be tested and validated through task performance assessment.

award_title: Elegant Decision Centered Visualizations Reducing the Cognitive Gap
research_keywords: User Interface,Human Machine Interface,visualization,display,WORKSTATION,Analysis,cognitive systems engineering,Joint Cognitive System
abstract: Users struggle with data overload and the disconnect that is created when data is presented in multiple, disjointed viewers. Resilient Cognitive Solutions understands the underlying causes of that struggle, and how to avoid them.First, in order to increase cognitive performance the visualization techniques must be more resilient to novel situations and provide improved error detection and recovery. Users must be able to better cope under a variety of stressors such as data overload and alarm avalanches. Ironically, applying technologies often worsens the overload when they unintentionally add cognitive work to operate the system itself and increase data volume by adding alerts and messages. The challenge is how to add technology affordances that aid decision making without burdening the user. Secondly, the system must reduce overall cognitive load leading to a natural ability to function more effectively. The visualizations must transform the data into the required mission information to match the core cognitive work a user is performing. Lastly the system must allow a user to process and analyze the information presented without the added burden of managing multiple tools and widgets. The visualizations must be coordinated and be arranged to mimic the users functional understanding of the world.

award_title: Simple Cognitive Based Visualization
research_keywords: 3D battlefield visualization,light-field displays,novel 3D light-field visualization paradigms,confident collaboration,lower cognitive load,significant retention improvement,natural perception,intuitive  holographic representations,intuitiveholographic representations
abstract: Human binocular vision and acuity, and the accompanying 3D retinal processing of the human eye and brain are specifically designed to promote situational awareness and understanding in the natural 3D world.The ability to resolve depth within a scene whether natural or artificial improves our spatial understanding of the scene and as a result reduces the cognitive load accompanying the analysis and collaboration on complex tasks.A light-field display projects 3D imagery that is visible to the unaided eye (without glasses or head tracking) and allows for perspective correct visualization within the displays projection volume.Binocular disparity, occlusion, specular highlights and gradient shading, and other expected depth cues are correct from the viewers perspective as in the natural real-world light-field.The intent of this effort will be to research, define and develop novel 3D light-field visualization paradigms that support the dynamic projection of perspective correct, full-parallax 3D data in a natural manner without the encumberment of head-mounted displays or head tracking in order to reduce the cognitive load on the warfighter.This effort will allow the warfighter the ability to understand and interpret the operating environment quicker and with greater confidence, thereby increasing the effectiveness of warfighter decisions and actions.

award_title: Ultraviolet Raman Explosives Detection System
research_keywords: Raman imaging,explosives detection,ultraviolet Raman,chemical detection
abstract: To address the Armys need for a portable and fast explosives detection device, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Ultraviolet Raman Explosives Detection (UVRED) system based on a novel combination of hyperspectral imaging techniques and a compact optical design, as well as well-understood explosive Raman signatures. Specifically, the hyperspectral imaging techniques adapted for Raman imaging will enable the UVRED system to quickly detect explosives residue on a 4cm^2 area at a distance of >1m. As a result, this system offers scan times of

award_title: Portable Ultraviolet Raman Imaging Sensor for Trace Explosives Detection
research_keywords: Raman,spectroscopy,Ultraviolet,imaging,Explosives,trace,Portable,sensor
abstract: Spectral Sensor Solutions proposes a combined experimental and analytical evaluation of innovative state-of-the-art technologies to design an optimal portable UV Raman imaging instrument for the detection of trace explosive residues. To accomplish this, we leverage our extensive experience in the phenomenology, spectroscopy, end-to-end modeling, electro-optical engineering and test and evaluation of UV Raman trace chemical and explosives sensors. Our sensor model predicts that our proposed design will meet the demanding requirements as stated in the solicitation. To demonstrate and confirm the performance of our design, we propose to perform technology evaluation experiments using our existing UV Raman sensor as a testbed system. This experimental component of the project will provide crucial verification of the sensor modeling results, resulting in high confidence that the proposed sensor design will perform as predicted.

award_title: Structurally Engineered High Conductivity Carbon Microfibers for FIR Obscuration
research_keywords: Far Infrared,obscurant,carbon nanofiber,conductivity,carbonization,Nanostructure,extinction coefficient,Nanotechnology
abstract: Obscurant materials play a crucial role in protecting the Warfighter by decreasing the electromagnetic energy available for the functioning of sensors, seekers, trackers, optical enhancement devices and the human eye. Current available materials for infrared wavelength application exhibit poor obscurant performance due to the low mass extinction coefficients in the aerosolization. In this project, Luna Innovations will develop a new class of highly conductive carbon nanofibers that are precisely tailored in dimensions and conductivity for optimal performance as obscurant materials blocking the far infrared (FIR) wavelength. A unique fabrication process is proposed which allows preparing these high conductive carbon nanofibers in large scale and low cost. These carbon nanofibers with the desired dimension and morphology may accurately match the customer requirements.

award_title: Intercalated Carbon Microfibers for Broadband Visible-IR Obscuration
research_keywords: Carbon microfibers,Infrared obscuration,INTERCALATION,conductivity
abstract: The U.S. Army has long recognized the potential of carbon based microfibers and nanofibers for use as obscurant materials.However, while base materials such as carbon nanofibers have demonstrated some of the most promising performance, a need exists to refine key aspects of the material to make it suitable for use as a broadband visible IR obscurant sought by the U.S. Army.Applied Sciences, Inc. (ASI), proposes to deliver the ideal visible-IR obscurant material by combining known and scalable processing techniques with its already established production and conductivity enhancement processing.These techniques and capabilities combined, will enable a precise control over the production, manipulation and transformation of high-aspect ratio carbon microfibers into effective engineered obscurants, which meet the targeted requirements set forth by the U.S Army. The development work will be further guided and informed by Prof. Charles W. Bruce team at New Mexico State University (NMSU).

award_title: Heuristic-based Prognostic and Diagnostic Method for Installations
research_keywords: Prognostics,DIAGNOSTICS,Heuristic,Modeling,Microgrid,installation,equipment
abstract: As microgrids have become a viable solution for reliable, resilient power at military installations, a larger focus on the existing infrastructure has emerged.Installation microgrid equipment must operate efficiently and effectively for a microgrid to be successfully implemented and operated.Through our participation in the Smart Power Infrastructure Demonstration for Energy Reliability and Security (SPIDERS) Joint Capabilities Technology Demonstration (JCTD) (see Related Work), we have witnessed the negative impact aging legacy equipment has on the integration of an intelligent microgrid control system.Thus, as microgrids will become more commonplace at military installations, it is critical that prognostic and diagnostic information about all microgrid equipment is available.A forward-leaning, sequence or heuristic-based prognostic and diagnostic (P&D) method will be an ideal solution for this issue.Resultant P&D datasets can be used to inform risk management processes to bolster the availability and resiliency of installation power systems.

company: INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF VIRTUAL ORGANIZATIONS, INCORPORATED
award_title: Creating a Run to Failure Simulation of Standby Generators Using Intermittent Data
research_keywords: Data-driven models,non-linear time series analysis,reliability,Prognostics,DIAGNOSTICS,Condition-based maintenance,Generator,Degradation
abstract: The DoD desires prognostics and diagnostics tools to proactively address the degradation of microgrid equipment legacy infrastructure for installation energy. Specifically in this SBIR, the tools should be able to identify long-term generator and power distribution performance degradation.It is not cost-effective nor is the data available to develop physics-based performance models on the myriad of generator sizes, applications, distribution, and age. Hence, we focus on evidence-based quantitative methodologies. Our technical objectives for this feasibility study are to:1. Collect operating data of a common diesel generator that is deployed across multiple configurations for both installation and operation energy needs.2. Apply methods such maximum overlap discrete wavelet transforms for feature extraction and filtering to determine the influence of environmental factors, grid interconnections, maintenance protocols, and similar external factors to create normalized time series for modeling.3. Develop non-linear diagnostic and prognostic models that identify change points for condition-based maintenance, determine remaining useful life, and uncertainty.4. Define a dedicated software solution that can reside on a commercially available power control system.In keeping with the stated purpose of the SBIR program, this project will produce fundamental research that can be commercialized for government and private enterprise markets.

award_title: Probabilistic Operations Warranted for Energy Reliability Evaluation and Diagnostics (POWERED)
research_keywords: DIAGNOSTICS,Prognostics,generator reliability,performance degradation,continuous-time modeling,dynamic modeling,Probabilistic Modeling,PROBABILISTIC PROGRAMMING
abstract: Back-up power equipment, such as engine-driven generator systems, undergo performance degradation over time that can prevent them from functioning properly in critical situations. Ensuring the reliability of back-up power systems during power outages not only allows for the continuation of normal operations, but also can mitigate potential threats to national security. Improved diagnostic and prognostic approaches that more accurately determine the reliability and performance of generator and power distribution equipment can advise the maintenance or replacement of power systems to prevent failures in critical situations, protecting against future threats. The Probabilistic Operations Warranted for Energy Reliability Evaluation and Diagnostics (POWERED) application uses rich, modular probabilistic modeling that advises reliability and maintenance of generators. POWERED uses a distributed network of continuous-time dynamic probabilistic relational models (PRMs) to accurately and efficiently diagnose and predict system- and component-level failures due to long-term degradation.

award_title: Visual and Physical Footprint Reduction of Parachutes on the Ground
research_keywords: footprint reduction,debris field minimization,aerial delivery,camouflage,concealment,parachute recovery
abstract: During air drop operations, payloads are dropped from high altitudes; reaching the ground attached to one or more parachutes. Parachutes become visual markers for enemy combatants to find the attached payload before friendly forces can reach it. Additionally, while airdropping Unmanned Vehicles (UV) the parachute has the potential to land on top of the vehicle, entangling the UV, covering important sensors impairing the UVs effectiveness, or altogether aborting the vehicles mission.Available research has indicated retracting the parachute can limit the parachutes visibility and footprint by reducing snaring, snagging, entangling of the canopy and steering lines, or parachute landing on top of the UV or payload. The addition of concealment/ camouflage further reduces the possibility of alerting enemy combatants. Methods of concealment vary based on the type of material and size of the payload.Commercializing the combined technology of a camouflaged, retracting device has a wide range of potential markets and customers including other DoD customers, telecommunications industry, environmental agencies, humanitarian groups, and oil, gas, and mining industries.

award_title: Visual and Physical Footprint Reduction of Parachutes on the Ground
research_keywords: Self Camouflage,transparent,Rapid Degradation,low visual signature,canopy fabric,Rapid Collapse,Polymer Additives. High Strength.
abstract: CTW Development LLC (CTW), working with Infoscitex Corporation (ISI), proposes to carry out an Army Phase I SBIR project (A16-060): Visual and Physical Footprint Reduction of Parachutes on the Ground.The research will evaluate three specific approaches to solving the problem.Bringing the parachute quickly to the ground.Rapid degradation of the parachute fabric structure once on the ground.Making the parachute inherently less visible.These approaches will be fully evaluated and data developed that potentially allows the technology to be applied to the development of a functional parachute canopy. Focus will be on providing a high strength, low weight parachute canopy that will acquire a low visual and physical footprint once reaching the ground.CTW/ISI, are well suited to be successful in this Phase I project with over 100 years of direct experience in R & D in fiber forming polymers, new fiber/fabric development, textile surface modification and the development/commercialization of innovative textile materials. CTWs competitive advantages include the ability to support low volume/specialty applications, access to vertical manufacturing yarn extrusion through finished fabrication, in-house expertise in development/production/marketing of technical textiles, and dedication to delivering high value products and customer success.

award_title: Parachute Olefin-polysulfone Obfuscating Film (POOF)
research_keywords: olefin polysulfone,depolymerize,joule heating,cross chute,Wire
abstract: MORSE Corp proposes to develop the Parachute Olefin-polysulfone Obfuscating Film (POOF) airdrop concept. POOF consists of a canopy constructed of transparent olefin polysulfone films that depolymerize into a benign gas when raised above a tunable transition temperature. The films depolymerization will be triggered by Joule heating, with a secondary transience mechanism utilizing free radical generation via photo initiators. This material approach to the reduction in parachute visual and physical signaturecan be applied to round chutes as well as ram air parafoils.

award_title: Continuous Mode Conveyor Cooking Appliance for Unitized Group Rations (UGR-A) for Military Field Feeding
research_keywords: continuous mode conveyor,heat transfer modes,cooking appliance,group rations,jet impingement,Microwave
abstract: Modern military field kitchens are required to provide high volume throughput while maintaining the best quality of group feeding rations for the Warfighter.The Army's legacy JP-8 fired appliances fall short, relying on inefficient burner units that subject cooks to excessive heat, exhaust, and noise.The Army needs one appliance designed to military standards.There is an opportunity to develop a reliable, continuous mode conveyor cooking system that prepares military UGR-A rations that would eliminate the need for an entire kitchen ensemble.The combination of high heat transfer of hot air impingement and microwave energy has the potential to produce high volume throughput results with high quality.Army cooking appliances need to be modular, man portable, and operate in all military environments. Texas Research Institute Austin, Inc will team with JetSweep Solutions, LLC to establish technical feasibility by demonstrating the modular conveyor cooking appliance will meet the operational and environmental requirements.The technical hurdles will be addressed with laboratory environment testing and performance characterization through experimentation.The supportability, safety, and human factors concerns will be addressed along with estimates of size, weight, cost, and performance.The components will be tested to critical military environments as outlined in MIL-STD-810G.

award_title: Continuous Mode Rapid Cooking Appliance for Military Field Feeding
research_keywords: Field kitchen,rapid cooking,microwave combination oven,jet impingement oven,military rations,field feeding
abstract: Feeding troops in the field is arguably the most critical component of force sustainment.The Army has been engaged in a multi-year effort to improve the fuel-fired appliances used in field kitchens for preparing UGR-A ration menus.This effort is primarily intended to improve the energy efficiency and environmental conditions of field kitchens.A range of different appliances are provided in field kitchens to enable military cooks to correctly prepare each menu component to a high quality level so that it has maximum appeal to soldiers.However, even using the latest appliances, ration preparation requires significant time by well-trained cooks to produce a quality result.The potential exists to improve the efficiency of military field feeding by developing a single cooking appliance that combines the rapid cooking capability of microwave combination ovens with the continuous (and rapid) cooking capability of jet impingement conveyor ovens.This would enable a single appliance to prepare any UGR-A menu item in a more compact kitchen using fewer personnel who require less training, while maintaining the level of quality achieved by fully equipped field kitchens.

award_title: Interlocking Gecko-Inspired Microfiber/Microridge Interfaces for Flexible, High Pressure Resistant Chem Bio Closure Systems
research_keywords: closures,dry adhesives,chem/bio defense,biomimicry,microfabrication,Fasteners,Sealing,gecko
abstract: The threat posed by the effective delivery of lethal Chem/Bio (CB) agents remains one of the key concerns in the defense against catastrophic attacks today and into the foreseeable future.There are many situations where a high pressure resistant, flexible, hermetic closure system is required to protect against such exposure.Conventional fastening options for such applications generally consist of zippers, hook and loop closures, or zip-track systems. However, these systems all include problematic drawbacks for critical applications. Among other deficiencies, zippers and hook and loop systems are inflexible, not decontaminable, and do not provide hermetic sealing for high pressure applications. Zip-track systems are difficult to install and use in field conditions, require secondary closures at the end of the track, and take on creases in storage which make them susceptible to permeation. We hypothesize that we can design and fabricate improved compliant closure systems which incorporate areas of interlocking microfiber/microridge adhesive arrays inspired by the foot-hairs found on geckos with continuous elastomeric interfaces to provide excellent sealing properties, even for high pressure applications. In this project, steps will be taken to develop, prototype, and characterize this novel family of flexible fasteners, and demonstrate their effectiveness for CB protection applications.

award_title: Flexible High Pressure CB Protective Closure System
research_keywords: closure,Seal,C/B agents,flexible,shelter,Air transportation
abstract: One of the most difficult challenges in CB protective systems is the closure because this area must be opened and closed and handled in difficult environments.Current CB protective systems are typically made from flexible base materials which requires the closure to be flexible. Current closures typically use zippers, hook and loop, or track closures. These standard closures limit the usefulness of the CB protective system because these closures do not seal well, especially at high pressures and are difficult to use in the field.A new closure system is proposed that is flexible, seals at high pressure, is CB resistant, reusable, cost effective, and can be decontaminated using standard techniques.

award_title: Adjustable Reusable Platform for Expeditionary Military Shelters
research_keywords: Collapsible Extruded Plastic Panel,CEPP,Expeditionary Platform,Ryzing Technologies,Frame system,Collapsible
abstract: The Principal Investigator for Ryzing Technologies has been designing, fabricating, deploying, and training soldiers on expeditionary shelters and accessories for more than a decade.He was a key part of transitioning the AirBeam Shelter from an SBIR with NSRDEC to commercialization with Force Provider.This experience of designing and producing products that improve the environment of warfighters gives Ryzing Technologies the confidence that they can deliver the best Adjustable Reusable Platform for Expeditionary Shelters.The proposed system will use a frame system that is deployed and leveled, without any tools, prior to installation of the flooring panels.The flooring panels are Collapsible Extruded Plastic Panel (CEPP) that have a low cost, good insulation value, and pack size of a third the deployed size.The CEPP enables over four thousand square feet of platform to be packaged into one TRICON container, which is at least twice the area of a non-collapsible insulated panel system.This system will not only meet the price point of $7.50 per square foot but will also provide a significant reduction in transportation cost.With the experience, system design, and military and commercial connections, Ryzing Technologies is a company that will successfully commercialize this system.

award_title: MODULAR EXPEDITIONARY PLATFORM SYSTEM (MEPS)
research_keywords: Lightweight FOB shelter platforms,Expeditionary platform system,Reusable FOB shelter platform,Rapid FOB shelter platform deployment,Rapid FOB shelter platform leveling,Interlocking FOB shelter platform tiles,Modular Expeditionary Platform System,ME
abstract: To overcome the limitations, costs, and risks associated with built in place wooden platforms, Hy-Tek Manufacturing Co. Inc. herein proposes an innovative approach to drastically increase the capabilities of raised platforms used for expeditionary shelters on forward operating bases. This approach involves the development of a Modular Expeditionary Platform System (MEPS). HMCs proposed MEPS concept is intended as a cost effective replacement to the currently used raised wooden platforms, which when deployed, will significantly reduce the costs the logistical burdens associated with transporting construction materials needed for specialized construction of FOB shelter platforms. MEPS will providing the American warfighter with a reliable, stable shelter platform that is easily constructed, level adjustable, insulated and reusable. The innovative geometry and design of this interlocking platform system will facilitate expeditious construction of forward operating base shelters at significantly lower cost than currently possible while improving the quality of life of forward operating base residents.

award_title: A Multi-Purpose Novel Biofidelic Head Surrogate to Evaluate Head Protection Systems from Ballistic, Blast, Sound, and Blunt Exposures
research_keywords: Human Head/Neck Surrogate,Military Helmet Protection,Ballistic Injury,Blast injury,Traumatic Brain Injury,Biomechanics,Blunt Injury,blast waves
abstract: The goal of this project is to design, fabricate, and demonstrate an easily reproducible and biofidelic head and neck surrogate to evaluate head protection systems from ballistic, blast, sound, and blunt exposures/threats.The CFDRC/APL team has extensive experience developing surrogate solutions to measure these types of threats and proposes creating a multi-purpose design which can be adapted to measure each threat of interest.In Phase I, a comprehensive requirements investigation will lead to a solution space where a trade-off analysis of the initial designs features can be made.Based on this analysis, a preliminary head/neck surrogate design will be developed leveraging our teams past work.Emphasis in the Phase I effort will be put on delivering a complete virtual preliminary design and during the Option period, conducting small scale prototype materials testing.Phase II will expand the materials development/production resulting in a full scale head/neck prototype to be delivered during the program.The finalized design will be computationally investigated to assist in creating test protocols for all current and future head protection systems.Incorporating COTS sensor solutions and easily reproducible materials for the head/neck surrogate, the overall cost of the head/neck surrogate can be kept low to allow repeated testing.

award_title: Adaptation of Ferrium M54 for Personal Armor
research_keywords: personal armor,Ferrium M54,severe plastic deformation,Ultra-fine grain size,grain size stability,nanostructured reinforcement,ICME
abstract: QuesTek Innovations LLC proposes to adapt its patented Ferrium M54 alloy for personal armor applications. The US Army Soldier Protection and Individual Equipment (SPIE) Program indicates the need for the development of Small Arms Protective Inserts (SAPIs) and Side Ballistic Inserts (SBIs) that will be able to protect the Soldier from threats such as basic small arms, sniper threats, and armor piercing threats while also providing a 10% weight reduction. This weight reduction is thought to be achievable via processes which will fabricate ultra-fine to nanoscale grains within the microstructure of the alloy, increasing the specific strength.In this Phase I SBIR program, QuesTek Innovations, a leader in the field of integrated computational material engineering (ICME), proposes to use an ICME informed test matrix to adapt Ferrium M54 to personal armor applications through fabrication of an ultra-fine grained, nanoreinforced microstructure. With its partners, Dr. Jonathan Montgomery, and Prof. Suveen Mathaudhu, QuesTek believes that Ferrium M54 is a good candidate for this application due to its high grain boundary cohesion, nanosized carbides, and high specific strength.

award_title: Agile Navigation and Guidance Enabled by LIDAR (ANGEL)
research_keywords: lidar,Sense and Avoid,Shadow UAS,fiber laser,ROIC,Collision Avoidance,Eye Safe Operation,SWIR
abstract: Advanced technologies in the area of high pulse rate fiber lasers operating in the eye safe SWIR spectral region, large linear focal plane array geometries, fast sampling Read Out Integrated Electronics (ROICs), and agile beam steering enable the Agile Navigation and Guidance Enabled by LIDAR (ANGEL) active sensor system to substantially meet the requirements for Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) to have an effective sense and avoid capability.The compact, Low SwaP-C sensors design is compatible with deployment on such UASs as the Shadow RQ-7.

award_title: Airborne Based Sense and Avoid (ABSAA) Sensor for Tracking Non-cooperative Aircraft for RQ-7 Shadow and Larger UAS
research_keywords: ABSAA,UAV,Multispectral,Radar
abstract: A low cost, size, weight and power multi-spectral sensing solution will be developed that will enable the RQ-7 Shadow and larger Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) to integrate into the National Airspace System (NAS) to meet training and other mission needs.The Airborne Sense and Avoid (ABSAA) sensing capability will be integrated with the Ground Based SAA(GBSAA) to support the full spectrum of desired unmanned operations.A fully qualified and automated ABSAA capability will also enable the future vision of automated UAS operations in the National Airspace System to include operations where one operator controls multiple UAS. The ABSAA will allow UAS to fly with fewer operational restrictions to enable dynamic operations during emergency response and during military operations. The ABSAA Sensor will adhere to the standards that are defined under the ODASD Open System Architecture (OSA) initiative which will allow for affordable change, employ evolutionary acquisition and spiral development.

award_title: Back Extraction Blast Seat
